clinical_study.brief_title: New Families- Innovation and Development of the Child Health Services in Oslo
clinical_study.official_title: New Families- Innovation and Development of the Child Health Services in Oslo

brief_summary.textblock: The New Families (NF) program will improve quality of existing services, secure personalised service and early intervention in Child Health Service (CHS) in Oslo. The study will measure the effects of a primary prevention family-centered healthcare intervention in Norwegian CHS.

detailed_description.textblock: The New Families (NF) program will improve quality of existing services, secure personalised service and early intervention in Child Health Service (CHS) in Oslo. The study will: 1) Measure the effects of a primary prevention family-centered healthcare intervention in Norwegian CHS, 2) Create case studies from CHS praxis advancing Public Health Nurse (PHN) training and education in Oslo and Norway, 3) Establish a model for how to include users in service development in CHS, 4) Enhance the knowledge base of the PHN practice in CHS Anticipated results: The project will bolster the knowledge base for education and professional practices within the service by strengthen the existing research within the field. The anticipated results of the project are that the intervention will increase maternal and parental self-efficacy, reduce the risk of postpartum depression among first-time mothers, reduce parental stress, increase social support, improve maternal attachment, improve generic health status, improve partner relationship and improve child development compared with usual care. The intervention research in this project can be a future model for service improvement in the CHS.

primary_outcome.description: Edinburgh postnatal depression scale (EPDS). 10 items. Score 0-30. Score 12 or above indicate postpartum depression.

primary_outcome.measure: Depression in fathers when partner is pregnant
primary_outcome.description: Edinburgh postnatal depression scale (EPDS). 10 items. Score 0-30. Score 12 or above indicate postpartum depression.

primary_outcome.measure: Depression in mothers three months postpartum
primary_outcome.description: Edinburgh postnatal depression scale (EPDS). 10 items. Score 0-30. Score 12 or above indicate postpartum depression.

primary_outcome.measure: Depression in fathers three months postpartum
primary_outcome.description: Edinburgh postnatal depression scale (EPDS). 10 items. Score 0-30. Score 12 or above indicate postpartum depression.

primary_outcome.measure: Sense of Coherence in mothers in pregnancy
primary_outcome.description: Sense of Coherence Scale (SOC 13). 26 items. Score 13-90. Higher score is positive, score under 66 is low.

primary_outcome.measure: Sense of Coherence in fathers in pregnancy
primary_outcome.description: Sense of Coherence Scale (SOC 13). 26 items. Score 13-90. Higher score is positive, score under 66 is low.

primary_outcome.measure: Sense of Coherence in mothers three months postpartum
primary_outcome.description: Sense of Coherence Scale (SOC 13). 26 items. Score 13-90. Higher score is positive, score under 66 is low.

primary_outcome.measure: Sense of Coherence in fathers three months postpartum
primary_outcome.description: Sense of Coherence Scale (SOC 13). 26 items. Score 13-90. Higher score is positive, score under 66 is low.
Perceived Maternal Parenting Self-Efficacy (PMP S-E) 20 items. score 22-88. A higher score indicates a higher level of maternal self-efficacy
Perceived Maternal Parenting Self-Efficacy (PMP S-E) 20 items. score 22-88. A higher score indicates a higher level of maternal self-efficacy
Perceived Maternal Parenting Self-Efficacy (PMP S-E) 20 items. score 22-88. A higher score indicates a higher level of maternal self-efficacy
Perceived Maternal Parenting Self-Efficacy (PMP S-E) 20 items. score 22-88. A higher score indicates a higher level of maternal self-efficacy

primary_outcome.measure: Parental Stress in fathers 3 months postpartum
primary_outcome.description: Parental Stress Scale (PSS) is formatted in the form of an 18-item self-report scale. Items represent positive (e.g. emotional benefits, personal development) and negative (demands on resources, restrictions) themes of parenthood. A higher score indicates a higher level of parental stress.

primary_outcome.measure: Parental Stress in mothers 3 months postpartum
primary_outcome.description: Parental Stress Scale (PSS) is formatted in the form of an 18-item self-report scale. Items represent positive (e.g. emotional benefits, personal development) and negative (demands on resources, restrictions) themes of parenthood. A higher score indicates a higher level of parental stress.

secondary_outcome.measure: What are the barriers and facilitators to implementation of the PHN intervention?
secondary_outcome.time_frame: The interviews will take place about 12 months postpartum
secondary_outcome.description: This research question will be explored by addressing the process of implementation. Data will be collected through a short survey and semi-structured interviews with PHNs and users (first-time mothers/fathers). An interview guide will be developed

arm_group.description: Supportive home visits by public health nurses to new parents from 28 weeks in pregnancy until the child is two years.
Follow up as usual at the Child health center

intervention.intervention_name: Supportive home visits to new families
intervention.description: The new families are offered home visits by a public health nurse from 28 weeks in pregnancy until the child is two years old. The number of home visits depends on the families needs and wishes. They also get the usual follow up from the Child health center.
Follow up at the Child health center according to national regulations

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- First time parents living in the chosen districts
Exclusion Criteria:
- All other parents

patient_data.ipd_description: There will be four doctoral students (PhD) in the project
